title-group.article-title: The Relationship Between ADHD Symptoms, Mood Instability, and Self-Reported Offending

article-meta.aff: 2University of Iceland/Landspitali—The National University Hospital of Iceland, Reykjavik, Iceland

author-notes.corresp: Gisli H. Gudjonsson, King’s College London, Institute of Psychiatry, De Crespigny Park, Denmark Hill, London, SE5 8AF, England, United Kingdom. Email: gisli.gudjonsson@kcl.ac.uk

abstract.p: Objective: To investigate the relative importance of ADHD symptoms, mood instability, and antisocial personality disorder traits in predicting self-reported offending. Method: A total of 295 Icelandic students completed two scales of offending behavior and measures of ADHD symptoms, mood instability, and antisocial personality traits. Results: Self-reported offending from the two independent scales correlated significantly with ADHD symptoms, mood instability, and antisocial personality traits with medium to large effect size. Multiple regressions showed that ADHD symptoms contributed to the two outcome measures beyond that of age and gender with a medium effect size. The ADHD effects were only partly mediated by mood instability and antisocial personality traits for general offending but were almost completely mediated by the more reactive measure of antisocial behavior. Conclusion: ADHD appears to be a potential risk factor for general offending in its own right irrespective of the presence of comorbidity, whereas mood instability is more important with regard to reactive behavior.

body.p: ADHD is a childhood developmental disorder, but one or more of the three core symptoms—inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity—sometimes persist into young adulthood (Faraone, 2005). Polanczyk, Silva de Lima, Horta, Biederman, and Rohde (2007) estimated that the worldwide-pooled prevalence rate of ADHD among persons 18 years or younger is 5.3%. Mental health problems, delinquency, and antisocial personality disorder are commonly reported in people who have grown up with ADHD (Barkley, Fischer, Smallish, & Fletcher, 2004; Barkley, Murphy, & Fischer, 2008; Biederman, Newcorn, & Sprich, 1991; Brassett-Grundy & Butler, 2004; Mordre, Groholt, Kjelsberg, Sandstad, & Myhre, 2011; Satterfield et al., 2007; Sibley et al., 2011; Sourander et al., 2006; Unnever, Cullen, & Pratt, 2003; Young, Gudjonsson, Ball, & Lam, 2003; Young, Wells, & Gudjonsson, 2011).

It is sometimes assumed that the relationship between ADHD and offending is substantially mediated by low self-control with relatively small direct effect (Unnever et al., 2003), although there is some evidence that, regardless of comorbidity, ADHD alone increases the risk of offending (Sibley et al., 2011). Young (2007) argued that ADHD is significantly related to early offending, which increases the likelihood of persistent offending into adulthood, even after taking into account comorbid conduct disorder problems in childhood. She suggests that the offending of adults with ADHD is likely to be unplanned and opportunistic and driven by a high level of impulsivity, need for stimulation, and mood instability. This is supported by the recent findings of Retz and Rosler (2010) who argued that ADHD is more strongly associated with reactive than proactive violent offending.

Young et al. (2010) found a younger onset of offending and a significantly higher previous rate of offending among ADHD prisoners compared with nonsymptomatic controls. Their total number of previous convictions, determined from official criminal records, showed that ADHD and heroin addiction were better predictors of the extent of their offending than antisocial personality disorder. ADHD was a better predictor of violent offences, even above prior drug use. Using the same data set, Young et al. (2009) found that ADHD was a much better predictor of the number of critical incidents within the prison than antisocial personality disorder. Similar findings have been reported among persons detained in forensic mental health facilities (Young et al., 2003). Investigating predictors of institutional disturbance, critical incidents with the institution, and previous offending in the community among adolescent offenders, Young, Misch, Collins, and Gudjonsson (2011) found that ADHD symptoms were more important in predicting institutional behavioral disturbance than conduct disorder, whereas substance misuse and violent cognitions were the best predictors of delinquency in the community. The findings from these studies suggest that ADHD is important in predicting behavioral disturbance and critical incidents within an institution. Gudjonsson, Sigurdsson, Young, Newton, and Peersen (2009) showed that mood instability is an important comorbid problem associated with ADHD, which may exacerbate existing propensities for poor behavioral inhibition and result in offending. In contrast, ADHD may be a less important predictor of offending in the community than antisocial personality disorder, but this has not been investigated in community samples. The preceding review raises important questions about the role of ADHD symptoms and mood instability in offending and how the nature of the offending (general offending versus more dynamic acting out behavior) influences this relationship.

The purpose of the present study was to investigate the relationship between self-reported offending, ADHD symptoms, mood instability, and antisocial personality disorder traits in a community sample of college students. It was anticipated that an antisocial personality disorder trait is the best predictor of self-reported offending among a community sample (Gudjonsson, Einarsson, Bragason, & Sigurdsson, 2006), but that ADHD symptoms and mood instability add a unique variance beyond that of an antisocial personality trait (Young, 2007). Self-reported offending behavior was measured by two different scales: The Mak Self-Reported Delinquency Scale, Total Offending Score (Mak, 1993), and the RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale (Young & Ross, 2007). The former is a direct measure of the extent of delinquent acts during the previous 12 months and thus a measure of general offending, whereas the latter is a more dynamic measure of acting out and reckless behavior (e.g., getting into a fight, threatening behavior, causing damage to property, reckless behavior, police contact) during the previous month.

Hypothesis 1 is that self-reported offending is correlated with antisocial personality traits, ADHD symptoms, and mood instability. Hypothesis 2 is that ADHD symptoms and mood instability are better predictors than antisocial personality traits of acting out behavior, but the reverse will be true of general offending (Young et al., 2009, 2011).

sec.title: Participants
sec.p: The participants were 295 students from four educational establishments in Iceland. There were 136 (46.4%) males and 157 (53.6%) females (two did not reveal their sex). Most of the participants (80.1%) were 16 to 18 years. A further 27 participants declined to take part in the study, which represented 8.4% of the total sample approached.

sec.title: Self-Reported Delinquency Scale
sec.p: This 34-item scale (Mak, 1993) records different kinds of delinquent acts and has been shown to have good reliability and validity (Gudjonsson et al., 2006). These range from minor antisocial acts (e.g., cheating at games or exams, truancy from school, drinking alcohol under age in a public place, consuming soft drugs) to more serious acts of delinquency (e.g., theft, using a weapon in a fight, fire setting, physical assault, driving a vehicle while intoxicated, and sexual assault). The participants indicate whether they had engaged in any of the delinquent acts in the past 12 months. In the current study, the formula devised by Sankey and Huon (1999) was used to determine the extent of delinquency in terms of the range and seriousness of delinquent activities. The mean seriousness score for each item is multiplied by the participant’s response to each item, giving a Mak Total Offending Score ranging from 0 to 474.

sec.title: RATE-S
sec.p: This is a 32-item self-report questionnaire (Young & Ross, 2007) of behaviors during the previous month. It comprises four subscales: (a) RATE-ADHD Symptoms (i.e., measuring attentional difficulties, impulsiveness, and disorganization); (b) RATE-Emotional Control (i.e., items relate to emotional volatility and include worries, anxieties, depressed mood, anger, loss of temper, and poor self-esteem); (c) RATE-Antisocial Behavior (i.e., involvement in a range of delinquent behaviors such as fighting, theft, damage to property, vandalism, reckless behavior, verbal threats to others, and being arrested and questioned by police); and (d) RATE-Social Functioning (i.e., items focus on social participation and confidence in social activities). Each item is rated on an 8-point Likert-type scale, ranging from “not at all” to “most of the time.” The possible score for each scale ranges between 8 and 64, with the possible total score ranging between 32 and 256. The RATE-S has been shown to have good reliability and validity (Gudjonsson, Sigurdsson, Eyjolfsdottir, Smari, & Young, 2009; Gudjonsson, Sigurdsson, Gudmundsdottir, & Sigurjonsdottir, 2010; Young & Gudjonsson, 2006).

sec.title: Barkley Current Symptoms Scale to screen for ADHD (BCS)
sec.p: This is an 18-item self-report questionnaire (Barkley, 1998) that corresponds with the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (4th ed.; American Psychiatric Association, 1994) criteria. In all, 9 items measure problems with attention and 9 measure symptoms of hyperactivity/impulsiveness. Each item was scored on a 4-point rating scale of frequency of symptoms from “never” to “very often.” The participants completed the questionnaire for symptoms they had experienced during the previous 6 months. Scores ranged between 0 and 27 for each of the two subscales (Inattention and Hyperactivity/Impulsivity) and 0 to 54 for the Total scale. Magnusson et al. (2006) reported the measure had good psychometric properties and correlated well with informants’ ratings of symptoms and interview-based diagnoses in childhood and adulthood in an Icelandic sample. The same measure has been used successfully in research into ADHD symptoms among Icelandic college students (Gudjonsson et al., 2010; Gudjonsson, Sigurdsson, Eyjolfsdottir, et al., 2009).

sec.title: Gough Socialization Scale
sec.p: This is a 54-item scale from the California Personality Inventory, which measures the extent to which individuals have internalized the values of society (Megargee, 1972). The lower the score the more likely the person is to possess antisocial personality traits (Gudjonsson & Roberts, 1985). It is a good measure of proneness to antisocial behavior (Blackburn, 1993), self-reported offending (Gudjonsson et al., 2006), reoffending (Sigurdsson, Gudjonsson, & Peersen, 2001), and reconviction after being released from prison (Peersen, Sigurdsson, Gudjonsson, & Gretarsson, 2004). Young and Gudjonsson (2006) found that the scale discriminated extremely well between patients clinically diagnosed with ADHD and normal controls with a large effect size (Cohen’s d = 2.6).

sec.title: Procedure
sec.p: The colleges selected were from three of the most heavily populated areas of Iceland. The questionnaires were administered to students in class in the presence of their teacher and the researcher during the first semester of the academic year. The researcher explained that the purpose of the study was to investigate the relationship between delinquency, ADHD, anxiety, and depression. It was further explained that participation was voluntary and that those who did not wish to take part were free to leave the class at any time. Those who remained in class, which comprised 91.6% of the total sample, completed the unmarked questionnaires anonymously and placed them into a sealed box held by the researcher. Ethical approval for the study was granted by the National Bioethics Committee in Iceland.

sec.title: Sex Effect
sec.p: To test for possible sex differences on the psychological tests, MANOVA was performed on the measures with sex as the independent (fixed) variable. There was a significant overall sex effect (Pillai’s Trace = .169; F = 4.8, p < .01; partial η2 = .169).

The mean test scores on the Mak Total Offending Score, RATE, BCS-ADHD, and Gough Socialization Scale were calculated separately for males and females. Independent t tests were conducted between males and females on the psychological tests and effect sizes (Cohen’s d) obtained on the three scales where significant difference emerged. The findings showed that males scored significantly higher on all three offending/socialization scales (Mak Total Offending Score, RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale, and Gough Socialization Scale). The effect sizes were large for the two offending outcome measures (Mak Total Offending Score, RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale; Cohen’s d = 0.58 and 0.61, respectively) and medium for the Gough Socialization Scale (Cohen’s d = 0.43). Alpha reliability coefficients showed acceptable reliability for all the scales ranging between .73 and .91 (see Table 1).

sec.title: Correlations
sec.p: Table 2 shows the Pearson’s correlations between the self-reported measures, antisocial personality traits, ADHD symptoms, and mood instability. The correlations are given separately for males and females. The correlations were generally larger for the female than male sample. BCS-ADHD symptoms, the Gough Socialization Scale, and the RATE-Emotional Control Scale all correlated significantly with the Mak Total Offending Score and the RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale with low to large effect sizes. The BCS-ADHD total symptom score correlated significantly with the Gough Socialization Scale (negative correlations) and the RATE-Emotional Control Scale with medium to large effect sizes. The table shows that the RATE-Emotional Control Scale is more highly correlated with the RATE-Antisocial Scale (large effect size) than with the Mak Total Offending Score (low to medium effect size).

caption.p: Intercorrelations Between the Psychological Scales for Males (Above the Diagonal) and Females (Below the Diagonal).

fn.p: Note: BCS = Barkley Current Symptoms Scale.

sec.title: Multiple Regressions
sec.p: With regard to the psychological variables, there was no violation of linearity, but there was violation of normality regarding the Mak Total Offending Score and the RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale. Violation of normality is not uncommon when large samples are used (Field, 2009). The collinearity statistics were acceptable (i.e., no variable had Variance Inflation Factor (VIF) greater than 1.0).

To investigate how much the BCS-ADHD total symptoms, the RATE-Emotional Control Scale, and the Gough Socialization Scale (i.e., the predictor variables of ADHD symptoms, mood instability, and antisocial personality traits) contributed to the variance in past offending (Mak Total Offending Score) and more current antisocial behavior (RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale), hierarchical multiple regressions were carried out using a forced entry method. Separate analyses were carried out for the two outcome (dependent) variables, and the findings are summarized in Tables 3 and 4. The predictor variables were entered in four steps with gender (male = 1, female = 2) and age being entered first to adjust for their possible effects, followed in Step 2 by the BCS-ADHD symptoms, RATE-Emotional Control Scale in Step 3, and the Gough Socialization Scale in Step 4. This allowed us to investigate the effects of ADHD symptoms on offending behavior and the extent to which the effects were mediated by poor emotional control and antisocial personality traits.

sec.p: The predictor variables accounted for 34.2% and 42.1% in “general” offending (Mak Total Offending Score) and antisocial behavior (RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale), respectively. For “general” offending, poor emotional control made no significant contribution to the outcome variable. The extent of offending was predicted by a combination of being a young male with antisocial personality traits and ADHD symptoms. Antisocial personality traits (i.e., a low score on the Gough Socialization Scale) were the single best predictor (β = −.408), and these partly mediated the effects of ADHD symptoms. Importantly, ADHD symptoms remained significant in the final step (β = .206) and had a stronger effect than being a male (β = .176) and of a younger age (β = −.137).

With regard to the RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale (Table 4), poor emotional control and antisocial personality traits almost fully mediated the effect of ADHD symp- toms (β value reduced from .418 to .075 and became nonsignificant). Poor emotional control remained the single best predictor (β = .374), followed by antisocial personality traits on the Gough Socialization Scale (β = −.270) and being a male (β = .253).

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Hypothesis 1 was supported by showing that self-reported offending (with the Mak Total Offending Score and RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale) correlated significantly with ADHD symptoms (BCS), mood instability (the RATE-Emotional Control Scale), and antisocial personality traits (the Gough Socialization Scale). The effect sizes were mostly medium to large. The Mak Total Offending and the RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale were highly correlated with large effect sizes (r = .54 and .64 for males and females, respectively).

In spite of the considerable overlap between the two outcome measures, multiple regression analyses showed that Hypothesis 2 was also supported. ADHD symptoms contributed to the two offending outcome measures beyond that of age and gender with a medium effect size, but, importantly, ADHD symptoms and mood instability had differential effects on offending behavior depending on outcome measure used. For “general” offending, antisocial personality traits proved to be the single most powerful predictor, followed by ADHD symptoms. Entering mood instability into the regression had no significant incremental effect, but entering antisocial personality traits mediated almost half of the effect of ADHD symptoms on offending. Therefore, for “general” offending, ADHD symptoms still had some significant direct effect on offending. This appears to support the recent findings of Sibley et al. (2011) that ADHD is a potential risk factor for offending in its own right, irrespective of the presence of comorbidity.

In contrast to “general” offending, the more dynamic acting out and reckless antisocial behavior measured by the RATE-Antisocial Behavior Scale was best predicted by mood instability, followed by antisocial personality traits. The marked and significant effects found for ADHD in Step 2 were largely mediated by mood instability. This finding is robust and indicates that the role of mood instability in mediating the relationship between ADHD symptoms and offending is dependent on the dynamic nature of the offending behavior. Therefore, in future research the nature of the offending and whether it is proactive or reactive need to be considered. These findings support the findings of Retz and Rosler (2010) about differences between reactive and proactive offending in their relationship with ADHD. Reactive offending is more strongly associated with ADHD than proactive offending, and the current findings support this.

In addition to the reactive and proactive nature of the offence, researchers have increasingly focused on the motivation behind offending (Gudjonsson & Sigurdsson, 2007). Gudjonsson, Wells, and Young (2011) recently showed that anxiety and mood instability as well as ADHD were related to the motivation for offending among prisoners. They found that drug dependence and ADHD symptoms were the most powerful predictors of financial motivation, alcohol dependence of provocation, and anxiety of compliance motivation. The results highlight the importance of ADHD symptoms, drug and alcohol dependence, and anxiety, in predicting the motivation of offending among imprisoned offenders.

The two main limitations of the study are its reliance on self-report and the cross sectional nature of the data. First, self-reported screening measures of ADHD symptoms lack diagnostic specificity (Barkley, Fischer, Smallish, & Fletcher, 2002; Kooij et al., 2008; Young et al., 2011). In addition, relying on a single reporter may inflate estimates of associations among the variables, and it is likely that lower estimates would have emerged if independent reports (e.g., from parents) had been available. Second, longitudinal studies are needed to investigate the pathways into offending at different stages of the life cycle and its persistence (Farrington, Ttofi, & Coid, 2009). Finally, it is recognized that self-reported ADHD screens lack sensitivity and specificity for a diagnosis of ADHD (Kooij et al., 2008). In the present study, the participants were not asked if they had been diagnosed with ADHD or were currently taking medication for ADHD. Such information has recently been found to be important in relation to police questioning and false confession (Gudjonsson, Sigurdsson, Sigfusdottir, & Young, 2011) and should be included in future studies in this area.

bio.title: Author Biographies
bio.p: Gisli H. Gudjonsson, CBE, obtained a PhD from the University of Surrey, England, in 1981. He is a professor of forensic psychology at the Institute of Psychiatry, King’s College, London, and a head of clinical and forensic psychology in the Lambeth Forensic Services at the South London and Maudsley NHS Foundation Trust. His main research interests are in the areas of forensic psychology, including police interrogation, false confessions, and motivation for offending. In 2009, the British Psychological Society granted him a Lifetime Achievement Award for his exceptional and sustained contribution to the practice of psychology. He was appointed a Commander of the Order of the British Empire (CBE) in the Queen’s Birthday 2011 Honours List for services to clinical psychology.

Jon Fridrik Sigurdsson obtained a PhD in psychology from King’s College, University of London, in 1998. He is a professor at the University of Iceland and Reykjavik University and the head of the Clinical Psychology Service at the Mental Health Services, Landspitali—The National University Hospital of Iceland in Reykjavik, Iceland. His main research interests are in clinical and forensic psychology, including understanding the behavioral problems of young people.

Thomas Frey Adalsteinsson obtained an MA in sport psychology from John F. Kennedy University, California, in 2011 and a BA in psychology from the University of Iceland in 2007. He works independently as a sport psychology consultant in the San Francisco Bay Area, coaches soccer and golf, and works with the sport psychology program at John F. Kennedy University. His main research interests are in sport and performance psychology, especially interventions to enhance performance and talent development.

Susan Young obtained a doctorate in clinical psychology from University College London in 1999 and a PhD in psychology from King’s College, University of London, in 1999. She is a senior lecturer in forensic clinical psychology at the Institute of Psychiatry, King’s College, London, and Honorary Consultant clinical and forensic psychologist at Broadmoor Hospital. Her main research interests are in the areas of ADHD and forensic psychology.
